conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to understand the relationship between the velocity of the conductor frame, the magnetic field, and the time it takes for an induced current to form.
The key is to use the formula for the time taken for an induced current to complete one cycle, which involves the speed of the frame, the distance it travels, and the magnetic field strength.
Identify the given values: Length of the conductor frame \( l \), Speed of the frame \( v \), Distance between the magnetic field boundaries \( d \), Magnetic field strength \( B \).
Understand the relationship between the magnetic field, velocity, and time for an induced current. The time \( t \) for an induced current to complete one cycle is given by \( t = \frac{l}{v} \).
Since the frame moves uniformly from left to right, the distance traveled by the frame is \( l \times t \).
The magnetic field strength \( B \) is constant. The induced current is proportional to the magnetic field strength and the velocity of the frame.
The time \( t \) is directly proportional to the magnetic field strength \( B \).
Since the magnetic field strength \( B \) is constant, the time \( t \) is also constant. Therefore, the time taken for the induced current to form is independent of the magnetic field strength.
Since \( l < d \), the time \( t \) is determined by the ratio of the length \( l \) to the speed \( v \).
Since the time \( t \) is independent of the magnetic field strength \( B \), the time \( t \) is determined by the ratio of the length \( l \) to the speed \( v \).
The time \( t \) is directly proportional to the length \( l \) and the speed \( v \).
Since \( l < d \), the time \( t \) is determined by the ratio of the length \( l \) to the speed \( v \).
